title: 114_s97
content: The Act may be cited as the "No Obamacare Kickbacks Act of 2015". The Congress finds that the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act applies civil penalties for violations of the False Claims Act to kickbacks involving Federal health care programs. The Center for Consumer Information & Insurance Oversight stated that the Department of Health and Human Services has broad authority to regulate the Federal and State Marketplaces. The CCIIO stated in 2013 that qualified health plans under the Affordable Care Act and Medicare Advantage plans are similar federal health care programs regulated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Both types of plans receive federal funding, with qualified health plans receiving subsidies through tax credits. The Federal Government facilitates applications and enrollment in qualified health plans through federally-funded call centers, web portals, and consumer assistance personnel, similar to how it is done for Medicare Advantage and Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit programs. The Medicare Advantage program is subject to anti-kickback provisions and other prohibited acts involving Federal health care programs. Violations involving Federal health care programs can result in civil and criminal penalties under the Social Security Act and civil penalties under the False Claims Act. The amendment clarifies the application of anti-kickback laws to qualified health plans, marketplaces, and programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. It includes plans funded under specific subtitles of the Act and related programs. The amendment is retroactively effective to the enactment of the Affordable Care Act. The amendment clarifies the application of anti-kickback laws to health plans and programs under the Affordable Care Act. The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the impact of anti-kickback laws on qualified health plans and programs under the Affordable Care Act. They will identify all relevant plans and entities benefiting from these laws. The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the impact of anti-kickback laws on qualified health plans and programs under the Affordable Care Act. They will identify entities benefiting from these laws and estimate the impact of excluding certain plans from the definition of "Federal health care program." The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the impact of anti-kickback laws on qualified health plans and programs under the Affordable Care Act. The study will assess the exclusion of certain plans from the definition of "Federal health care program" and report on key details such as health care premiums, consumer choice in insurance coverage, drug usage, and the net cost of the Affordable Care Act to the Federal Government and all States and territories. A report will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Inspector General and Comptroller General will provide a report with recommendations for legislative or administrative action based on specified information in subsection (a).
